Added new IRM 8.7.1.11 for overview of criminal restitution.

Guidelines for Cases with Special Issues 8.7.1

This section provides guidance on identifying criminal restitution-based assess- ments (RBAs). Technical Services (TS) has exclusive responsibility for completing assessments on criminal restitution cases where IRC 6201(a)(4) is applicable. The case will only be sent to Appeals to consider the civil liability. Appeals employees must never adjust the RBAs. See IRM 8.7.1.11, Overview of Criminal Restitution-Based Assessment Process.

) The research credit has been extended numerous times with one gap: no credit is allowed for amounts paid or incurred after June

The Protecting Americans from Tax Hikes Act of
made research credit permanent. (

) Use care to ensure the correct law and applicable regulations are applied when computing the research credit for any taxable year. a. See the Appeals Issue Locator at https://organization.ds.irsnet.gov/sites/ APPEALS-PQCS/Lists/Issu

ocator/Search.aspx for more information about the Research Credit. b. Additional information can be found at the Business Credits Issue Group’s web site at General/default.aspx Note: The Deﬁnition of a Qualiﬁed Activity under Section

is an Appeals nated Issue – Category of Case and requires a referral to Technical Guid- ance, but does not require Review and Concurrence. Two other issues involving the Research Credit, Extraordinary Utilities and Allocation of Indi- rect Costs to Self-Constructed Supplies, are Compliance Coordinated and they require both a referral to Technical Guidance and Review and Concurrence. (
) Form

, Credit from Increasing Research Activities, provides for the computations of the research credit, the reduced credit and the amount of suspended research credit. Refer to the corresponding revision of the form instructions for the applicable taxable year. (
) The Tax Reform Act of
added the research credit to the general credit (GBC) for years beginning after
Prior to that it was a credit. As part of GBC, it is subject to the carryback and carryforward provi- sions of IRC
) Special rules apply where both the credit and a deduction is claimed for the same research expenditures. a. IRC
C(c)(

) provides that no deduction is allowed for that portion of the qualiﬁed research expenses otherwise allowable as a deduction for taxable year which is equal to the amount of the credit determined for such taxable year. b. The taxpayer must reduce deductions by the amount of the credit computed, regardless of whether the taxpayer is able to utilize the full credit in the credit computation year, unless the taxpayer elects a research credit pursuant to IRC
C(c)(
). c. This is a yearly election and may be claimed only on an original timely ﬁled return (with extensions). d. See IRC
C(c) for details and prior law. e. ATEs must take IRC
C into consideration when providing the Tax putation Specialist with the adjustments to the research expenditures the research credit.
) The research credit has been extended numerous times with one gap: no credit is allowed for amounts paid or incurred after June

made research credit permanent. (

ocator/Search.aspx for more information about the Research Credit. b. Additional information can be found at the Business Credits Issue Group’s web site at General/default.aspx
IRC
C(c)(

) provides that no deduction is allowed for that portion of the qualiﬁed research expenses otherwise allowable as a deduction for taxable year which is equal to the amount of the credit determined for such taxable year. The taxpayer must reduce deductions by the amount of the credit computed, regardless of whether the taxpayer is able to utilize the full credit in the credit computation year, unless the taxpayer elects a research credit pursuant to IRC
C(c)(
). This is a yearly election and may be claimed only on an original timely ﬁled return (with extensions). See IRC
C(c) for details and prior law. ATEs must take IRC
C into consideration when providing the Tax putation Specialist with the adjustments to the research expenditures the research credit.

) The Tax Relief Extension Act of
provides for two suspension periods the research credit. As a result, credit arising from these suspension periods cannot be taken into account on original returns. a. First suspension period is July
– September
: The cannot be taken into account prior to the later of October
b. Second suspension period is October
– September
: credit cannot be taken into account prior to October

) No credit involving the two suspension periods may be claimed on a timely ﬁled or late ﬁled original income tax return, even if that original return is ﬁled after the expiration of such suspension period. The amount can only be claimed on a Form

) Further, any claim for refund of an overpayment of tax attributable to a research credit suspension period cannot be ﬁled before the expiration of applicable suspension period or before the date the original return for the plicable taxable year is ﬁled. (
) See Notice
and IRM
, Business Tax Returns and Non-Master Accounts, Income Taxes/Information Returns, for additional information on research credit suspension periods. (

) To determine the amount of the credit that is suspended, the taxpayer must ﬁrst calculate the research credit for the taxable year. a. Because the research credit suspension periods merely delay the use of research credits attributable to a research credit suspension period, the limitations contained in IRC
(c), IRC
, and IRC
(g) on the of research credit allowable to any person as a credit against tax for taxable year remain applicable. b. Further, taxpayers not electing to take a reduced credit under IRC
C(c)(
) must continue to reduce applicable deductions, amounts chargeable to capital account, and credits for the taxable year by the full amount of the research credit as required by IRC
C(c)(
) and IRC
C(c)(
) The amount of the total credit that is suspended is based solely on the of months in the ﬁscal year before the suspension date (October
or October

) and the number of months after the suspension date, not the dollar amounts incurred for qualiﬁed research activity during the suspen- sion periods. Any adjustment to the credit amount is to be allocated to the different periods before and after the suspension date. See the examples below: a. Example

) Any research credit not allowed in the taxable year that is attributable to a research credit suspension period may not be claimed as a carryback or forward until the day after the end of the applicable research credit period. After the end of the applicable research credit suspension period, however, research credits attributable to a research credit suspension period not used currently as a credit against tax may be carried to other taxable under the rules of IRC

) During these suspension periods, the research credit is not used to any amount required to be paid for any purpose under the Internal Revenue Code. This restriction extends to the determination of underpayments for the computation of penalties and additions to tax. (
) In general, additions to tax for failure to pay estimated tax are made under
or IRC

for any underpayment of income tax imposed by the Code even if the underpayment is created or increased because of the suspension of the research credit. No additions to tax for failure to pay estimated tax, however, are made for any period before July
, for any of income tax imposed by the Internal Revenue Code to the extent the payment is created or increased by reason of the suspension of the credit. See Notice

In determining estimated tax payments, a credit created by a claim for research credit can only be applied to an estimated tax payment that is due after the suspension period expires. An example of this is a credit to the second suspension period cannot be used to reduce any estimated payment due before October

Technical and Procedural (

) The purpose of this section is to make ATEs aware of Art Appraisal (AAS), and to encourage contact with this office when needed. The office Issues in maintains a core of ﬁnancial analysts and art appraisers to assist service Cases personnel on their cases. In addition, AAS can assist ATEs in locating in other ﬁelds. (
) The ATE consults with AAS on any case claiming a value for a single work art in excess of $

Telephone discussions with this office are encour- for Art aged in order to take advantage of expert advice and to facilitate the Service of all referrals for valuation assistance. To determine information and items necessary to obtain valuation assistance on works of art, see IRM
, Valuation Assistance Procedures, for detailed instructions and procedures. (
) Requests for AAS’s assistance must be submitted through the online Referral System (SRS). Referrals may be created at https://srs.web.irs.gov/ default.aspx. (

) Requesters are encouraged to contact the valuation specialists by informally discuss a valuation problem to determine the type of assistance required. For detailed instructions and procedures, see IRM
, Assistance Procedures. (
) Code Section
provides for administrative and judicial reviews for and termination assessments. and (
) Appeals procedures for termination assessment cases are in many the same as for jeopardy assessments. Cases (
) The following subsections provide procedures for processing these cases. (
) Jeopardy assessments are made under IRC
or IRC
These sections provide an expedited assessment procedure when tax collection is Assessments endangered if regular assessment and collection procedures are followed.
allows the Service to presume that tax collection will be jeopardized certain circumstances where an individual is in physical possession of an identiﬁed large amount of cash. a. IRC
applies to assessments of deﬁciencies of income, estate, gift and certain excise taxes b. IRC
applies to taxes other than income, estate, gift and certain excise taxes whether or not the due date for ﬁling and paying the tax expired. (
) Service policy on jeopardy assessments is found in Policy Statement Also see IRM
, Jeopardy and Terminations, and IRM

) Under IRC
(a), the Compliance Area Director has ﬁve (

) days after a jeopardy assessment to furnish the taxpayer with a written statement of the Assessment information the Service relied on in making the assessment. See IRM for Jeopardy, Termination, Quick and Prompt Assessments, for a pattern letter.
8.7 Technical and Procedural Guidelines
a. IRC
applies to assessments of deﬁciencies of income, estate, gift and certain excise taxes b. IRC
applies to taxes other than income, estate, gift and certain excise taxes whether or not the due date for ﬁling and paying the tax expired.

Under IRC 7429(a), the Compliance Area Director has ﬁve (5) days after a jeopardy assessment to furnish the taxpayer with a written statement of the information the Service relied on in making the assessment. See IRM 5.1.4, Jeopardy, Termination, Quick and Prompt Assessments, for a pattern letter.

) As a result of the enactment of the IRS Restructuring and Reform Act of on July
, it is now a statutory requirement for Chief Counsel or delegate to approve all jeopardy and termination assessments and all levies. See IRC

) Jeopardy assessments initiated by Collection personnel are limited to proposed: a. Trust Fund Recovery Penalty assessments; b. Employment and excise tax assessments, whether or not the return due date expired; c. Partnership penalty assessments; d. Income tax assessment when there is no question about the amount of the liability. (
) A jeopardy assessment is requested: a. when it is determined collection is in jeopardy; b. when one or more of the four conditions outlined in Policy Statement P-
exists; c. for Trust Fund Recovery Penalty assessments, and IRC
(b) ments, for which appropriate appeal/protest periods are not expired; d. when assessment/collection action is proposed after the return due date for a signed return for income tax liabilities. (

) Examination occasionally investigates cases pending in Appeals to the need for a jeopardy assessment. An investigation by Examination is to whether collection of any proposed deﬁciency is endangered by any in stance that might adversely affect the taxpayer’s ability to pay or the Government’s ability to collect. Appeals is responsible for making the ﬁnal termination of the tax liability in controversy. (
) If Examination determines that a jeopardy assessment is not warranted, the Area Director returns the case to the Appeals Office with a notice to that (

) When a jeopardy assessment is warranted, it is made by the Area Director. The case and jeopardy assessment ﬁle are immediately returned to the nation function that referred the case. In income, estate and gift tax cases, Appeals issues any notice of deﬁciency required by IRC
(b). Send a of the notice of deﬁciency to the appropriate Examination function. (

(b) permits a taxpayer to seek judicial review of a jeopardy nation of the appropriateness of the amount of the jeopardy assessment. period for seeking judicial review is the earlier of the

Technical and Procedural (

) Some jeopardy assessments lend themselves to complete resolution of both the merits of the liability and the reasonableness of the jeopardy Therefore, both aspects can be resolved by agreement if the action is taken within
days after the taxpayer’s request is ﬁled or the taxpayer decides to request judicial review of the assessment in District Court. (
) The Area Director makes a termination assessment under the conditions in Policy Statement P-
and the procedures in IRM Part
Time for holding Appeals conferences, rendering a prompt decision, and statutory provisions for ﬁling suit in District Court are the same as for jeopardy ment. (

) Because of time limitations involved, if the taxpayer provides new or documentation to the ATE, the Area Director may need to promptly comment on the new evidence. Appeals retains jurisdiction over the case in instances where the Area Director comments on the new evidence. (
) Inform the taxpayer of the right to judicial review under IRC
(b) when a taxpayer does not agree with the Appeals decision. Return the case ﬁle and report, in duplicate, to the Area office Examination function. (
) At the end of the full tax year, the taxpayer is required to ﬁle a full year Generally, Examination is responsible for issuing the notice of deﬁciency required under IRC
(b) for the taxpayer’s taxable year. Area office and Campus controls are established to determine whether or not the taxpayer a full year return. (

) Examination either examines the taxpayer’s return or prepares a substitute the return. The taxpayer may protest the notice of deﬁciency and come to Appeals. In some cases, it is possible for Appeals to receive the case prior issuance of the notice of deﬁciency. In these cases, Appeals issues the of deﬁciency. If Appeals issues the notice of deﬁciency, a copy of the notice sent to the appropriate Examination function. (

) The Department of Justice (DOJ) has exclusive jurisdiction over any action which a taxpayer has ﬁled a suit in the United States District Court or in the United States Court of Federal Claims for recovery of taxes paid. (

) When a suit for refund of taxes is ﬁled and the taxes at issue are part of a pending case, further consideration is postponed on the case, including all years under consideration (suit and nonsuit) and on any related cases. (

) However, it is not necessary to postpone consideration for years not in litiga- tion if the issues in the nonsuit years are unrelated to the issues in the years under litigation. In such situations, contact the DOJ through local Associate Area Counsel (to obtain permission to consider non-suit years). (
) Either the Campus or Associate Area Counsel notiﬁes the appropriate office when a suit for refund is ﬁled in a case pending before Appeals. See IRM
, Offer in Compromise, for suits involving offers in compromise. (
) Appeals is notiﬁed when the case jurisdiction changes to Department of Justice (DOJ), exclusively. of Internal Revenue Manual Cat. No.

) This section explains procedures for handling Refund Suits in various scenarios. It provides information on the following: Procedures on • When to issue the notice of claim disallowance. Suits • What to do if the case involves an application to reconsider a claim viously disallowed. • What information should go in the Appeals Case Memorandum. • What to do before issuing a statutory notice of deﬁciency on the years. • What happens if the taxpayer ﬁles a petition with the Tax Court. • How to handle related cases that are in Appeals for consideration. , Appeals Transmittal and Case Memo and identify the case as a in Appeals case. (
) Forward the return to APS for processing, who will complete the actions and promptly send the administrative ﬁle, including the return, to Counsel. (

) However, if the Campus maintains a follow-up control on the Refund ﬁle, APS will forward the administrative ﬁle to the Campus, referring in the transmittal to the Campus’s Refund Litigation control number. (

, Waiver of Statutory Notiﬁcation of Claim Disallowance, was not signed by the Suits with issue a statutory notice of claim disallowance. of Pending (

to transmit the return to APS and enter date the notice of claim disallowance was issued or the date Form
ﬁled. Finally, advise the taxpayer that, because of ﬁling suit, the case is jurisdiction of the DOJ and Appeals will give no further consideration to case. (

) Before issuing a notice of deﬁciency on the suit years, consult with the through Counsel, for advice and concurrence. If the DOJ concludes a Suits with deﬁciency should be issued, they notify Counsel, who notiﬁes the Notice of Appeals office. Issued (
) If the notice of deﬁciency raises an issue under a speciﬁc Internal Code section or Tax Court Rule

that places the burden of proof on Government with respect to the issue, consider sending the proposed Counsel for consideration. There is no need to consider sending the notice to Counsel if the burden of proof issue involves only IRC
) Notify Counsel if you have information that the taxpayer intends to Tax Court after receiving a notice of deﬁciency.

After the ATE prepares the case for release to DOJ, APS will close the case on AIMS and ACDS, recharge the administrative ﬁle and send it to Counsel.
This section explains procedures for handling Refund Suits in various scenarios. It provides information on the following:

When to issue the notice of claim disallowance. What to do if the case involves an application to reconsider a claim viously disallowed. What information should go in the Appeals Case Memorandum. What to do before issuing a statutory notice of deﬁciency on the suit years. What happens if the taxpayer ﬁles a petition with the Tax Court. How to handle related cases that are in Appeals for consideration.
Notify Counsel if you have information that the taxpayer intends to petition the Tax Court after receiving a notice of deﬁciency.

) If the DOJ receives a proposal of settlement in a case previously of Justice by Appeals that affects only years in suit, Counsel does not refer the to the Appeals office for comment unless circumstances warrant (

) If a disaster occurs and the President declares the area to be a “federally declared disaster area”, FEMA will designate certain areas within the area to be eligible for Individual Assistance under the Robert T. Stafford Disaster Relief and Emergency Assistance Act,

U.S.C., Sections (Stafford Act). Because taxpayers and tax practitioners may require disaster/ emergency relief measures to enable them to meet their tax obligations for ﬁling returns or paying taxes without being penalized, the IRS will provide and payment relief to affected taxpayers located in the areas designated by FEMA to be eligible for individual assistance. Certain compliance actions be temporarily suspended - in accordance with IRC
A, Authority to Postpone Certain Deadlines by Reason of Presidentially Declared Disaster Terroristic or Military Actions.
with Special Issues
page (

) The Disaster Assistance and Emergency Relief Program is a service-wide program under the stewardship of SBSE, Communications and Stakeholder Outreach (CSO), Stakeholder Liaison (SLHQ). The Director of CSO issues a Memorandum for Distribution stating that the president declared a “disaster area identiﬁed by the Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA)” to eligible for individual assistance under the Stafford Act. This memorandum identify the speciﬁc disaster, the disaster date (or beginning disaster date), declaration date, “speciﬁc acts postponed,” the IRS designated disaster area(s), etc. The memorandum is for internal use only. The taxpayer can obtain external notices at www.irs.gov in the section entitled, Tax Relief in Di- saster Situations. See Appeals’ Disaster Assistance and Emergency Relief page for additional information, including links to speciﬁc disaster assistance declarations. (
) The Director of FEMA appoints a Federal Coordinating Officer (FCO) to nate FEMA’s disaster assistance efforts and work with other federal agencies on relief issues. (

) IRS will issue a Notice of Disaster Declaration from FEMA that identiﬁes the disaster, incident period, the FCO, the IRS designated area(s), and type of sistance available. The IRS Notice of Disaster Declaration can be amended, additional designations are made after further evaluation. However, the randum for Distribution (previously issued by CSO) is not changed as a result of additional designations. The Appeals Technical Employee (ATE) should on the instructions contained in the CSO’s Memorandum for Distribution to determine the speciﬁc acts postponed, account freezes, the requirement for stuffers and/or soft contact letters, etc. (
) The IRS IT organization (Information Technology) identiﬁes the “affected taxpayers” by zip codes in the designated disaster areas. (

) Role of Appeals - Appeals will follow the guidelines contained in the CSO’s Memorandum for Distribution and IRS’ Notice of Disaster Declaration from FEMA. Appeals will take the following steps after IT has identiﬁed the taxpayers in the designated disaster areas - by zip codes: • A Planning Quality and Analysis (PQ&A) program analyst will prepare spreadsheet with a list of all Appeals inventory identifying taxpayers located in the IRS covered disaster area(s). The PQ&A analyst will forward the list to the designated Policy program analyst. In addition, PQ&A will include the following email attachments: (a) CSO’s dum of Distribution and (b) the IRS Notice of Disaster Declaration from FEMA. • A Policy analyst will send an e-mail notice (with attachments) to Area Technical Advisors, who will determine the need to forward information to the Appeals team level. The Policy analyst’s email will contain reminders for the ATE to consider the need for Notice

, Disaster Relief from the IRS and/or soft contact letters, as directed in CSO’s Memorandum for Distribution. • Appeals Policy requires the input of the “DR” (Disaster Relief) feature code on ACDS for “affected taxpayers” identiﬁed for suspension. If the ATE has not identiﬁed the taxpayer for suspension, the “DR” feature code should not be added. The ATE can determine the need to action by sending the taxpayer a “soft contact letter” to determine the effect of the disaster on the taxpayer. The ATE can ﬁnd a sample “soft contact letter” on Appeals’ Disaster Assistance and Emergency Relief Internal Revenue Manual
for Cases with Special Issues 8.7.1

) In a criminal tax case, a court may order a defendant to pay restitution to the Service for tax related losses. Criminal Investigation (CI) provides evidence the courts for the amount of restitution to be ordered. The amount of the tution ordered by the court is calculated from evidence submitted at trial or from information contained in the plea agreement and presented to the court sentencing. The court issues a Judgment and Commitment Order (J&C) after the sentencing hearing. (
) CI is required to close its case and notify the Service civil functions within

days of ﬁnal adjudication of the amount of restitution ordered. Final adjudica- tion occurs the day after all appeals have been exhausted for the criminal case. The J&C often only speciﬁes a single amount of restitution that covers multiple tax years or periods. When notifying the civil functions of the amount of restitution via Form
, Notiﬁcation of Court Ordered Criminal Payable to IRS, it is the responsibility of the CI special agent to specify whether the restitution is assessable as a tax and how it should be See IRM
, Criminal Investigation, for more information. (

) When the criminal aspects of the case have been completed, e.g., criminal prosecution is concluded or the criminal investigation is discontinued, CI will notify the Service civil functions including Examination Technical Services Internal Revenue Manual Cat. No.

) In a criminal tax case, a court may order a defendant to pay restitution to the Service for tax related losses. Criminal Investigation (CI) provides evidence to the courts for the amount of restitution to be ordered. The amount of the resti- tution ordered by the court is calculated from evidence submitted at trial or from information contained in the plea agreement and presented to the court at sentencing. The court issues a Judgment and Commitment Order (J&C) shortly after the sentencing hearing. (
) CI is required to close its case and notify the Service civil functions within

days of ﬁnal adjudication of the amount of restitution ordered. Final adjudica- tion occurs the day after all appeals have been exhausted for the criminal case. The J&C often only speciﬁes a single amount of restitution that covers multiple tax years or periods. When notifying the civil functions of the amount of restitution via Form

, Notiﬁcation of Court Ordered Criminal Restitution Payable to IRS, it is the responsibility of the CI special agent to specify whether the restitution is assessable as a tax and how it should be assessed. See IRM
, Criminal Investigation, for more information. (

) When the criminal aspects of the case have been completed, e.g., criminal prosecution is concluded or the criminal investigation is discontinued, CI will notify the Service civil functions including Examination Technical Services (TS)

) The Office of Appeals is not authorized to consider or process criminal tion appeals. Appeals must not abate or adjust any restitution-based assessment. The defendant ordered to pay restitution may be one or more of, but is not limited to, the following:
8.7 Technical and Procedural Guidelines

• Individual taxpayer (e.g., ﬁling an individual return, a separate return, a joint return) • Officer or employee of a corporation • Partner or employee of a partnership • Employee of a sole proprietorship • Corporate director • Client of a return preparer • Return preparer • Tax shelter promoter • BMF entities (corporations, partnerships, trusts etc.). (

) Because restitution debts stem from the same underlying tax liability, the full amount can only be collected once. Any payments that wholly or in part the restitution-based assessment (as a result of the criminal case) will also applied against the underlying tax liability (if assessed) provided that the restitution-based assessment is attributable to the underlying civil liability (if liability is not the same as the amount ordered by restitution, they will not be mirrored). Example: If the restitution is for tax period X but relates to the defendant’s business income tax and not his own personal income tax for the period, the payment would be credited to his RBA and the business income tax liability. It would not be credited to his personal income tax liability for the same period. (
) Duplicate assessments include the RBAs made on the appropriate MFT
account, and civil tax and/or penalties assessed on each respective party’s underlying tax account. (
) Two responsible parties may owe different duplicate assessments amounts the same period. The duplicate assessments may or may not be equal to RBA amount and can be identiﬁed by a TC
AC

This is not an all-inclusive list, but is representative of the most frequently encountered criminal statutes that may result in a restitution-based assessment. (

) A criminal restitution (CR) is also referred to as a restitution-based (RBA). Examination Technical Services (TS) has exclusive responsibility for completing assessments on criminal restitution (CR) cases where IRC
), Assessment Authority, is applicable. (
) The following provisions are helpful in interpreting IRC
): a. The RBA is assessed as if it was a directly assessable tax and does not require the issuance of a statutory notice of deﬁciency (SNOD)(IRC
)). b. The amount of the restitution cannot be challenged in a civil or judicial proceeding based on the existence or amount of the underlying tax liability (IRC

)(C)). c. The Office of Appeals does not consider appeals of RBAs. d. If an appeal is ﬁled on the criminal restitution determination, the appeal is under the sole jurisdiction of the Department of Justice. e. The assessment of the restitution as if it were a tax can be made at any time and is not subject to a statute of limitations (IRC
)). f. An RBA under IRC

)(A) can be no greater than the amount ordered as restitution. If the court ordered restitution includes interest, the assessment may be less than the amount ordered, since interest is sys- temically calculated, and to include it would be to double assess the interest. g. Interest under IRC
accrues on the RBA. Comments reﬂected on the J&C Order referring to interest under Title
do not have any bearing on the RBA or the Title
interest owed on the RBA. The Service does not have jurisdiction over Title
interest. The defendant is required to pay the Title
interest directly to the court, when applicable. The criminal court can waive the Title
interest on the restitution ordered, but the court cannot waive the Title
interest on the RBA. (
) For more information, refer to CC-
, The Assessment and Collection Criminal Restitution, and IRS Chief Counsel Notice CC-
, Deﬁciency and Litigation Issues Concerning Tax Periods For Which Criminal Restitution Has Been Ordered. (

The criminal RBAs against an individual are posted on the individual defen- dant’s MFT
module(s). The duplicate civil assessments (when applicable) are posted on the appropriate module for the type of civil tax on which the criminal restitution is based (MFT
, MFT
, MFT
, etc.). Refer to IRM
, Assessing Restitution, for more information on cases where the restitution may be ordered against an entity.

Note: For BMF assessments not assessed on MFT 31, be careful not to abate any portion of the actual restitution assessment amount if you are considering any adjustments to the civil assessment(s). While there may be abatements,
8.7 Technical and Procedural Guidelines

either due to added expenses, less income, or Net Operating Loss carry- backs, do not abate more than the non-restitution assessments (TC 150, TC 290, TC 298, TC 300, TC 308, etc.). A Restitution assessment is court ordered, and cannot be reduced without the court issuing an order. If there are any questions, please contact the Technical Services (TS) office in Los Angeles, CA (at *SBSE TECH Svc Criminal Restitution).

) After the restitution assessment process has been completed, the local Exami- nation Local Technical Service (TS) fraud coordinator will review the referral package from Criminal Investigation and determine whether civil examination actions are warranted. Field Examination is responsible for reviewing case ﬁles forwarded by TS to complete the following actions: a. Taking appropriate civil actions, including the recommendation not to take further civil action, to conduct a limited or in-depth civil examination,
Taking appropriate civil actions, including the recommendation not to take further civil action, to conduct a limited or in
depth civil examination, and/or prepare applicable audit reports as warranted based on the facts and circumstances of the case.
Cases with Special Issues
page b. Recommending the assertion of any applicable civil penalties. c. Forwarding the completed examination case through TS for mandatory review prior to closure. (
) A restitution case may also be a Condition of Probation (COP) case. CI and Compliance (Examination/Collection) share primary responsibility for tax-related COP for the Service. See IRM
, Special Conditions of Probation, IRM
, Report to Criminal Investigation When Convicted Taxpayer on Probation, and IRM
, Conditions of Probation. (

) On unagreed protested cases and petitioned statutory notice of deﬁciency cases, the TS fraud coordinator will send notiﬁcation of an RBA and/or COP case sent to Appeals by sending an email to the Appeals ″Condition of Probation Case Coordinator″. The COP Case Coordinator is listed under the Appeals ″Contacts″ section of the following website: directory/contacts.htm. This email is forwarded to an Account and Processing Support (APS ) delegate who will search Appeals Centralized Database Sys- tem (ACDS) for the Appeals’ COP/RBA new receipt. After the case is added ACDS, APS inputs the PB feature code on ACDS to allow for Appeals COP/ RBA Case tracking. (
